Steam is doing a great service by resurrecting classic games like MOO2. This is a great game I have been playing for over 20 years and I am delighted to have a version that will play on newer versions of Windows. Like any retro game, the graphics, video, and sound is several generations behind today, but far superior to the standard of those just a year or two older, like the original MOO (which comes bundled with this.) 

MOO2 is a 4X game that has reasonably deep gameplay in terms of worlds, races, tech, etc. The animations of new discoveries are better than even some newer games (it's fun to see a 360 view of a new fusion rifle or such.) The races are interesting and can be customized. As with the original, the real fun is building your ships to fit your own style and taste. Tactical combat will not wow by today's standards, but is sufficiently gratifying to actually see how well, or not, your design decisions are working. I personally prefer using modified Elerians. Their psionics are great for conquering worlds with a minimum of destruction and since the ground combat system is fairly weak (no tactics), you aren't missing much. Also, MOO2 introduced leaders to the system. Unlike its cousin, Master of Magic, the leaders provide some entertaining spice to worlds and battles, but are not overpowering. 

The other great thing about MOO2 were the choices the player gets to make, including three paths to victory, ranging from election, to domination, to defeating the mysterious Antarans in their own dimension. 

Although you have to love the original, and some platers still prefer it, to me MOO2 is the best in the series and still a lot of fun 20 years on. It is definitely superior to the much less graphic and dull MOO3, whicn Steam seems to be avoiding like most players did. Of course, it would be nice to see the pack expanded to include the legendary MoM as well!

There is always something new to discover and figure out. Employing a new strategy that no one else has ever seen, and to see it work, is a great feeling!

One of the best parts of MoO2, is ship design and ship combat. This is where turn base outshines real time. You get to decide what technologies, systems, and weapons go into the ship. This game is pretty awesome. 
It's like Civ, but I would say it's more sophisticated than its contemporary, civ2. It's also in space.
The only problem is that it is difficult for beginners. It's not that it's incredibly difficult (at least on the right levels), but more that there's nothing resembling a tutorial. MOO2's version of "Civilopedia" is pretty sparse as well. The good news is that you can right-click on almost anything and it'll be explained. 
The other thing that bugs me about this game (but I've only played like 1.5 hours so lol) is that is SO HARD TO EXPLORE. In civ, you can send out like one scout and he can explore the world. It might take a while, but there's not really any limit to how far he can go. In MOO2 the ships can only go 2 parsecs (which is almost nothing) away from your closest base, which means that you have to build a ton of bases in order to visit planets besides your next door neighbors. 
Despite these two issues, the game is still enjoyable. I love the thrill of picking a desolate planet and filling with colonists to subdue it and enrich you.
Graphics btw are AMAZING compared to my standards for 1996. Dozens of times better than Civ2, which looks pretty bad compared to this. They still hold up ok, but my standards are pretty low in the graphics department. The screenshots are representative of the game.
I say if you like 4X games, if you like space colonization games, or even if you're just a patient gamer looking for a good deal, get this game. I mean, MOO2 is like $6 and it includes the original Master of Orion. 

UPDATE: It turns out that the difficulty of exploring was because I was playing as the Klackons, who don't get to choose what technology they research in a given generation, and I happened to not get a chance to research a certain kind of fuel cells. Playing as other races (or even better, the Psilons) makes the game much easier.

Seufz... Das gute alte Master of Orion 2

Wohl kaum ein Game hatte so viel Einfluss auf meine Kindheit... es steht wohl tatsächlich auf einer Ebene mit Warcraft 3.

Und auch wenn mein Urteil wahrscheinlich von dieser emotionalen Verankerung getrübt ist, ist das Spiel mit Sicherheit auch objektiv gesehen ein herausragender Klassiker.

In diesem Gold-Standard der Weltraumspiele muss der Spieler durch technologischen Fortschritt und fortschreitende Expansion die Galaxie erobern. Dabei kommt es darauf an zwischen Forschung und Industrie abzuwägen, die richtigen Planten zur Besiedelung zu finden, die passenden Technologien zu erforschen oder anderes aufzutreiben und Notfalls auch mit Waffengewalt sein Territorium zu halten oder zu erweitern.

Es gibt dazu standardmäßige Rasse, die alle vor allem am Anfang des Spielens recht interessant sind und in gewisser Weise sogar einen eigenen eigenen Charakter (einen bestimmten Fokus) haben. Zwischen den Rassen entseht schnell ein munteres intergalaktisches Treiben mit Handelsverträgen, Allianzen und Spionageaktivitäten. Es ist auch möglich eigene Rassen zu erstellen, was vor allem nach dem ersten Einstieg eine tolle Möglichkeit das Spiel noch weiter zu erkunden darstellt.

Die Spielemechaniken zu verstehen und zu erlernen ist relativ einfach und trotzdem bietet das Spiel genug Features für Langzeitmotivation. Der Balanceakt zwischen Komplexität und Zugänglichkeit ist bei MOO2 besonders gut gelungen. 

Rundum hat man nahezu durchgehend irgendetwas das man noch schaffen will. Man will noch diese oder jene Technologie oder diesen oder jenen Planeten. Man möchte noch den nächsten Krieg gewinnen oder man möchte endlich Frieden schließen. Auch bieten einige Dinge wie die Antaraner oder Orion und viele andere Events und Specials reichlich Abwechslung. 

Ein rundum gelungenes Spiel

Nach heutigen Stand könnte man durchaus auch Dinge kritisieren. z.B. fühlt sich das Landwirtschaftssystem etwas sinnlos an. Zwar kann ich frei wählen, ob ich total über- oder unterproduziere in dem ich die Milljarden von Bürgern der Landwirtschaft zuordne oder abziehe, doch werde ich in den meisten Fällen jeden Zug versuchen auf ein +- 0 zu kommen. Bei größeren Imperien fühlt sich das dann eher als lästige Aufgabe denn als sinnvolle Spielemechanik an.

Auch das Taktische Kampfsystem ist nicht wirklich interessant und meistens eher ein Abgleich der Waffenstärke und weniger eine strategische Angelegenheit.
Noch dazu gibt es einige Technologien, die dem Spieler erlauben quasi unverwundbare Schiffe zu bauen (Phasendeckung, Zeitsprungakktuator). Dies ist bei deaktivierem Tactical Combat Gott sei dank nicht möglich.


Bester Moment: Die Zerstörung der Heimatwelt der Antaraner!

The very first game I ever played on the IBM when it was given to us back in 1995.  The one that gave us both the computer and the game absolutely insisted that we go with Strategic Combat only, but after a month of that I decided to try out Tactical combat.  I never looked back.

Playing on Easy difficulty was a challenge at first to get to know all the mechanics, but of course you have to gradually grow up the ladder to a higher difficulty.  My very first encounter with the Stellar Converter was on Easy difficulty.  A single ship was coming into my planet, so I sent my fleet to meet it at the planet expecting an easy win like usual.

That first turn the planet was annihilated by a squealing yellow beam that I had not seen before.  All defenses gone, all population gone.  Only my orbital was present with the five ships I sent.  I did not even learn what weapon it was until several years later when I actually took the time to read /all/ of the technologies in the game.

Ahhh, memories.  Nowadays I play on the hardest difficulty with very little trouble.  Not even the Silicoid ever pose a threat to me even if they send out 500 ships, but all I will ever need is one.  Phasing Cloak + Time-Warp Facilitator = Win...  Just need to WAIT until all enemy ships have moved that turn before attacking.  Otherwise, even with damper fields and Xentronium armor you're toast.

2 Stellar Converters (at 250 space apiece - Weapons Hypertech 6 required)
6 Tractor Beams
4 Assault Shuttles
99 Gauss Cannons (Heavy, Auto-Fire)
99 Gauss Cannons (Auto-Fire)
Any other weapons I want

Structural Analyzer (2x damage after shields penetrated)
Achilles Targeting Unit (Ignore armor, including Heavy Armor and Xentronium)

Damper Field
Slot 8 whatever I want to have at the time

History: MOO2 is almost 20 years old now (originally released in 1996) and it's still considered by most strategy gamers to be one of (if not THE) finest strategy game ever made. One of the developers that worked on Civ2 (also released by Microprose in 1996) said that when you win a tech victory in Civ2, and your rocket ship takes off to reach for the stars, Master of Orion 2 is what happens next.

Modern 4X space games are pretty much all based on the blueprint of Master of Orion 1&2, and yet none have surpassed it's perfect balance of strategy, depth, personality, optimisation and fun. And I know, I've played almost all them, from Space Empires, to Civ, to Stardrive and Endless Space via Total War and Sins of a Solar Empire, the list goes on and on, but this game; this game is the best.

Everything that people complain about with 4x games these days is often because it's been done better in MOO2. The main game interface is accessible and easy to pick up. There's numbers, but it's easy to understand what they mean. You have important decisions to make right from the start about what direction to send your empire in. The diplomacy matters. The races have personality. The research you choose really matters, and you have tough decisions every time you research a tech field. There's freighters and starbases  and farming and economy and morale and espionage, and it's all important, and it's all perfect. Not too complex, not too simple.
The turn-based tactical combat is tense and strategic, you get attached to your ships because you put every gun and system on that ship, you chose it's appearance and named it yourself, you spent the last 20 minutes building it and you know how it should be used in combat. This ain't no point n' click rts, it's fun, it's deep, and it's tactical.
This game has it all, and it does it all really, really well.
